Literature Review: Living structures, particularly plants, exhibit a remarkable array of forms and functions that have evolved over millions of years. These forms are not merely random but are the result of intricate interactions with both biotic and abiotic environments. Plants, as living machines, have developed specialized functional parts that enable them to sense and respond to environmental cues. This review aims to explore the engineering themes embedded in plant forms and functions, focusing on three key motifs: bilayer actuators, slender-bodied functional surfaces, and self-similarity. By examining these motifs, we can gain insights into the structure–function relationships that underpin plant biology and understand the evolutionary drivers that shape these forms.
